awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Dynamics of the Capital and Labor Allocation in the United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project measures how capital, labor, and other inputs are allocated across manufacturing firms and establishments by size, age, and other characteristics. They will use data from the Department of Treasury and the U.S. Census Bureau to calculate statistics that describe how these resources have been allocated across U.S. manufacturing firms, and how that allocation has changed over time.  The new measurements will be publicly available and will be used in models of the U.S. economy. The team also plans to use a business cycle accounting procedure to assess whether (and to what degree) changes in resource allocation help to create business cycle fluctuations. Finally, they will identify a set of economic frictions that are important for understanding business cycles. A large class of macroeconomic models starts with the behavior of individual firms, aggregates firms into industries, and then builds up to the production side of the entire US economy. The result of this project will be widely incorporated into these macroeconomic models. As a result we will better understand how government economic policies affect different industries and firms in different ways.

The team seeks to understand the role of frictions to resource allocation in shaping business cycle fluctuations. They will provide a publicly available set of reduced-form statistics that describe the dynamics of the allocation using high-quality Census micro data. Second, they will develop a semi-structural distributional business cycle accounting procedure to assess the contribution of changes in the allocation to aggregate fluctuations. Third, they will use the results of this procedure to identify the set of structural frictions that are quantitatively relevant for understanding aggregate fluctuations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Given the rich heterogeneity in firms' productivity, the allocation of resources across firms is crucial in determining aggregate economic outcomes. The goal of this project is to understand changes in resource allocation shape business cycle fluctuations. 

In this project, we constructed a set of statistics to describe the dynamics of the allocation of resources across U.S. manufacturing establishments using Census micro data. In the planned paper "Misallocation Over the Business Cycle" (by co-PIs Pablo Ottonello and Thomas Winberry), we plan to present the empirical findings from this measurement and use it to develop a semi-structural distributional business cycle accounting procedure that we will use to assess the contribution of changes in the allocation to aggregate fluctuations. 

We hope this project will have broader impacts for researchers, policymakers, and graduate student mentorship. The reduced-form statistics constructed in the project will be made publicly available so that researchers working with quantitative heterogeneous firm models can use statistics to parameterize their models or verify their predictions for the allocation of resources against the data. Policymakers may find these results useful by enabling them to assess the distributional effects of proposed policies across businesses rather than simply focusing on their aggregate impact. Finally, during the lifespan of the award, five graduate students worked as research assistants using U.S. Census data. These students were trained in frontier empirical methods and gained access to the Census microdata, which some of them have used for their dissertations.
